user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BinSemDelete:
```c
int32 OS_BinSemDelete(osal_id_t sem_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_BinSemDelete_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BinSemDelete:
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_BinSemDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t *sem;
    int32                             return_code;

    sem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_bin_sem_table, *token);

    if (pthread_cond_destroy(&(sem->cv)) != 0)
    {
        /* sem could be busy, i.e. some task is pending on it already.
         * that means it cannot be deleted at this time. */
        return_code = OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }
    else
    {
        /* Now that the CV is destroyed this sem is unusable,
         * so we must do our best to clean everything else.  Even if cleanup
         * does not fully work, returning anything other than OS_SUCCESS would
         * suggest to the caller that the sem is still usable which it is not.
         */
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

        /* destroy the associated mutex --
         * Note that this might fail if the mutex is locked,
         * but there is no sane way to recover from that (see above). */
        pthread_mutex_destroy(&(sem->id));
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(int32 operation_status, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    osal_id_t final_id;

    /* Clear the OSAL ID if successful - this returns the record to the pool */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        final_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;
    }
    else
    {
        /* this restores the original ID */
        final_id = token->obj_id;
    }

    /* Either way we must unlock the object type */
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, &final_id);

    /* Give event callback to the application */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_NotifyEvent(OS_EVENT_RESOURCE_DELETED, token->obj_id, NULL);
    }

    return operation_status;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I did not find code fragments that obviously violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 in the supplied snippets. Rationale for not flagging the pointer usages in the provided code: 

- OS_ObjectIdGetById(..., OS_object_token_t *token): The token argument is written to (token->obj_idx, token->obj_id) and used to start/abort a transaction; therefore it must be a non-const pointer and is correct as written.

- OS_BinSemDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token): This function already takes the token as a pointer-to-const and does not modify the token, so it follows the rule.

- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(int32 operation_status, OS_object_token_t *token): The function reads token->obj_id but also calls OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, &final_id). That finish routine is expected to operate on the token (e.g. to release locks or update state), so token must remain non-const; making it const would likely be incorrect. Without the implementation of OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish there is no evidence this pointer could safely be const.

- sem pointer in OS_BinSemDelete_Impl (OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t *sem) and the addresses passed to pthread_cond_destroy/pthread_mutex_destroy: the code performs destructive operations on the semaphore record (destroying the cond var and mutex), so non-const pointers are appropriate.

- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token): already const-qualified and correct.

Given the visible reads/writes and calls to other routines that presumably mutate the pointed objects, there is no clear candidate where a pointer should be changed to point to a const-qualified type. If you can provide implementations (or prototypes) of the called routines such as OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish or OS_ObjectIdConvertToken, I can re-evaluate whether any parameter could be declared const.
